questions.text: Which of the following is seen in neurogenic shock?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypotension and Bradycardia Hypotension and tachycardia mean the patient had developed Hemorrhagic shock(Chest/ Abdominal injuries) in trauma." Hypotension and Bradycardia in a trauma mean the patient had developed Neurogenic Shock".

Highyeild:

SHOCK : Shock is a systemic state of low tissue perfusion inadequate for normal cellular respiration . With insufficient delivery of oxygen and glucose, cells switch from aerobic to anaerobic metabolism. If perfusion is not restored in a timely fashion, cell death ensues . Classification of Shock : Hemorrhagic/hypovolemic shock (due to reduced circulating volume) Causes: Non-Haemorrhagic: Poor fluid intake (dehydration), Excessive fluid loss due to vomiting, Diarrhea, urinary loss (e.g., diabetes), Evaporation or ‘third spacing,’ where fluid is lost into the gastrointestinal tract and interstitial spaces, as for example in a bowel obstruction or pancreatitis. Haemorrhagic Cardiogenic shock (primary failure of the heart to pump blood to the tissues) Causes: Myocardial infarction Cardiac dysrhythmias Valvular heart disease Blunt myocardial injury Cardiomyopathy Myocardial depression caused by endogenous factors (e.g., bacterial and humoral agents released in sepsis) or exogenous factors, such as pharmaceutical agents or drug abuse Obstructive shock (reduction in preload owing to mechanical obstruction of cardiac filling) Cardiac tamponade Tension pneumothorax, Massive pulmonary embolus or air embolism In each case, there is reduced filling of the left and right sides of the heart, leading to low cardiac output. Distributive shock Causes: Pericardial tamponade Pulmonary embolus Tension pneumothorax IVC obstruction Deep venous thrombosis Gravid uterus on IVC Neoplasm Increased intrathoracic pressure Excess positive end-expiratory pressure Neoplasm Endocrine shock (Combination of hypovolaemic, cardiogenic or distributive shock) Causes Hypo­ and hyperthyroidism Hypothyroidism causes a shocking state similar to that of neurogenic shock due to disordered vascular and cardiac responsiveness to circulating catecholamines. Cardiac output falls as a result of low inotropy and bradycardia. There may also be associated cardiomyopathy. Thyrotoxicosis may cause a high output cardiac failure Adrenal insufficiency Shock due to hypovolemia and a poor response to circulating and exogenous catecholamines. Adrenal insufficiency may be due to preexisting Addison’s disease or relative insufficiency due to a pathological disease state, such as systemic sepsis.

options.label: C

options.label: D

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mostly Hereditary Most cases of gastric cancer are sporadic not hereditary The most widely used staging system- TM uses depth of invasion, nodal and distant metastases as prognostic indicators. Lauren's system classifies gastric cancer into Type I- intestinal and Type II- diffuse Intestinal type of cancer is characterized by mutations in the APC gene or B-catenin that causes increased signaling via the Wt pathway. Diffuse-type is characterized by decreased E-cadherin mainly due to loss-of-function mutations in the CDH1 gene. LAUREN CLASSIFICATION INTESTINAL TYPE DIFFUSE TYPE Environmental Familial Gastric atrophy, Intestinal metaplasia Blood type A M> F F> M Increasing incidence with age Younger age group Gland formation Poorly differentiated Hematogenous spread Transmural, lymphatic spread Microsatellite instability APC gene mutation Decreased E-cadherin (CDH1 gene) Inactivation of tumor suppressor genes p53, p16 Exophytic, bulky lesion Ulcerating lesion Frequent intraperitoneal metastasis. LINITIS PLASTICA

Highyeild:

Intestinal type: Environmental factors, such as gastric atrophy and intestinal metaplasia , are associated with its development. It is more common in men than women. Its incidence increases with age. It is characterized by gland formation and hematogenous spread. It is associated with microsatellite instability, mutations in the APC gene, and inactivation of p53 and p16. It occurs more commonly in the distal part of the stomach. It may have familial tendencies. It is more common in individuals with blood group A. Diffuse type: Women are more commonly affected than men. It occurs in a younger age group than the intestinal type. It may occur in endemic areas. It is more common in the proximal part of the stomach.

questions.text: In a patient with a carcinoma prostate with a high Gleason score, a bone scan was done. Bone scan shows increased bone uptake but reduced uptake in kidney and soft tissue. This is reported as a super scan. What is the likely cause for the above scenario:

options.label: A
options.text: Increased uptake due to diffuse metastasis

options.label: B
options.text: Due to low intake of an agent by kidney and soft tissue

questions.correct_answer: A. Increased uptake due to diffuse metastasis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increased uptake due to diffuse metastasis The super scan appearance is due to increased uptake due to diffuse metastasis. Diffuse osteoblastic metastatic diseases can lead to a generalized increase in the skeletal uptake relative to soft tissue and absent or faint renal activity on a bone scan. This is known as a super scan. It may also be seen in generalized bone diseases such as hyperparathyroidism.

Highyeild:

Metastasis : Local Spread Locally advanced tumors tend to grow upwards to involve the seminal vesicles, the bladder neck, and trigone and, later, the tumors tend to spread distally to involve the distal sphincter mechanism. Further upward extension obstructs the lower end of one or both ureters, with obstruction of both resulting in anuria. The rectum may become stenosed by tumor-infiltrating around it, but direct involvement is rare Spread by the bloodstream Spread by the bloodstream occurs particularly to the bone; indeed, the prostate is the most common site of origin for skeletal metastases, followed in turn by the breast, the kidney, the bronchus, and the thyroid gland. The bones most frequently involved by prostate carcinoma are the pelvic bones and the lower lumbar vertebrae. The femoral head, ribcage, and skull are other common sites Lymphatic Spread Lymphatic spread may occur via (i) lymphatic vessels passing to the obturator fossa or along the sides of the rectum to the lymph nodes beside the internal iliac vein and in the hollow of the sacrum and (ii) lymphatics that pass over the seminal vesicles and follow the vas deferens for a short distance to drain into the external iliac lymph nodes. From retroperitoneal lymph nodes, the mediastinal nodes and occasionally the supraclavicular nodes may become implicated.

Extraedge:

The median survival of men with metastatic disease is about three years

When vaccines cannot be given before emergency splenectomy, vaccines should be given at least two weeks after splenectomy. Following vaccines are given: Pneumococcal vaccine influenza type b vaccine Meningococcal vaccination Influenza vaccination

Highyeild:

Proper indications for laparoscopic splenectomy are important. Preoperative imaging is necessary to determine size, volume, and presence of accessory splenic tissue. Hand-assisted techniques should be considered, particularly in cases of splenomegaly. Contraindications such as portal hypertension and major medical comorbidities should be considered. Splenic vaccinations are crucial to reduce the risk of OPSI. Vaccinations for N. meningitides, S. pneumoniae, and Haemophilus influenza should be administered at least 14 days before elective splenectomy or 14 days after or upon discharge of an emergent splenectomy.

questions.text: The size 'F' in Foley's catheter indicates
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Outer Tube Diameter A Foley catheter is a thin, sterile tube inserted into the bladder to drain urine. Because it can be left in place in the bladder for some time, it is also called an indwelling catheter. The French scale corresponds to the external circumference in millimeters. French size divided by 3 will give the outer diameter of the catheter. size = 3 x d, where d is the outer diameter in mm An 18 Fr. catheter will have a circumference of approximately 18 mm and a diameter of 6 mm.

questions.text: An elderly female underwent Surgical resection of her bowel and, after a few months, presents with easy fatigability and tiredness. Clinical examination shows macrocytic Anaemia. Resection of all of the following can cause this except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Jejunum Causes of Low vitamin B12 levels. Cause Examples Low vitamin B 12 intake Vegetarianism, chronic alcoholism and older people Autoimmune Pernicious anaemia and Sjögren's syndrome Food-bound cobalamin malabsorption Atrophic gastritis, chronic gastritis and Helicobacter pylori-associated gastritis Surgery Post-gastrectomy and ileal resection Malabsorption Small intestinal bacterial overgrowth_ chronic pancreatic exocrine insufficiency, Crohn's disease, coeliac disease and achlorhydria Obstetric/gynaecological Oral contraceptive, hormone replacement therapy and pregnancy Genetic Transcobalamin II deficiency Drugs Metformin, proton pump inhibitors and histamine H2-receptor antagonists

Highyeild:

Gastrectomy can lead to metabolic defects. Anemia is the most common metabolic defect after gastrectomy. Iron deficiency anemia is more common than megaloblastic anemia caused by vitamin B12 deficiency after gastrectomy. Iron deficiency anemia after gastrectomy is caused by decreased iron intake, impaired iron absorption, and chronic blood loss. Megaloblastic anemia caused by vitamin B12 deficiency after gastrectomy is rare and depends on the amount of stomach removed. Poor absorption of dietary vitamin B12 due to the lack of intrinsic factors causes megaloblastic anemia after gastrectomy. Patients who have undergone subtotal gastrectomy should be given lifelong vitamin B12 supplementation . Osteoporosis and osteomalacia have been observed after gastric resection and are caused by deficiencies in calcium. Calcium malabsorption is aggravated by fat malabsorption after gastrectomy. Bone disease generally develops about 4-5 years after surgery. Calcium supplements and vitamin D treat osteoporosis and osteomalacia after gastrectomy. Patients who have undergone Billroth II or Roux-en-Y reconstruction that bypasses the duodenum should also receive supplementation of fat-soluble vitamins (vitamins A, D, E, and K) after gastrectomy.

questions.text: Which of these is the most life-threatening injury that can be identified while assessing the breathing component of the patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tension Pneumothorax ABCDE of trauma Airway and cervical spine control - Airway should be assessed for patency. Foreign bodies and vomit should be removed, and facial, mandibular, tracheal, and laryngeal injuries should be excluded clinically. Breathing and ventilation - The lungs, chest wall, and diaphragm must be assessed for potential acute injuries that could compromise ventilation. These injuries include tension pneumothorax, tension haemothorax, flail chest, and open pneumothorax Circulation and haemorrhage control - The patient's hemodynamic state must be assessed quickly and accurately. Any external source of bleeding should be identified and dealt with immediately using manual pressure. When the examination or history suggests internal injury, a pelvic radiograph should be taken, and limited ultrasonography (FAST) done to exclude hidden blood loss. Disability and neurological status - The patient's neurological state is assessed with the Glasgow coma scale. It is easy and quick to use and is a determinant of patient outcome and possible further management. Exposure and environment - The patient should be fully exposed (by cutting off all clothes) to allow a full examination. However, it is critical to keep the patient warm with blankets and a heated emergency room. Large volumes of fluids may be infused, and these intravenous fluids should be warmed. Tension pneumothorax is an uncommon condition with a malignant course that might result in death if left untreated. It is a severe condition that results when air is trapped in the pleural space under positive pressure, displacing mediastinal structures and compromising cardiopulmonary function. Treatment of tension pneumothorax is immediate needle decompression by inserting a large-bore (eg, 14- or 16-gauge) needle into the 2nd intercostal space in the midclavicular line.

Highyeild:

Tension pneumothorax is a medical emergency that can result in respiratory failure or cardiovascular collapse. It can be diagnosed clinically without the need for radiographic confirmation. The symptoms of tension pneumothorax include deviation of the trachea , unilaterally absent or diminished breath sounds, and cardiopulmonary compromise. If these symptoms are present, thoracic decompression should be rapidly performed with a large-bore needle or tube thoracostomy, depending on the availability of equipment and supplies.

Extraedge:

In addition to tension pneumothorax, massive hemothorax also requires tube thoracostomy with the evacuation of blood and reexpansion of the lung. Severe pulmonary contusion may require aggressive mechanical ventilation with elevated levels of positive end-expiratory pressure. However, to avoid loss of positive end-expiratory pressure, the ventilator should not be repeatedly disconnected for suction or manual ventilation as oxygenation will only improve with an uninterrupted circuit

questions.text: A 32-year-old female with Grave's disease with eye signs and enlarged thyroid is planned for a total thyroidectomy. What can be given in the preoperative period to reduce intraoperative bleeding in the patient:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lugol's Iodine Lugol solution (inorganic iodide) has been given preoperatively to patients to limit intraoperative bleeding and related complications resulting from thyroid

Highyeild:

Thyroidectomy is a treatment option for patients with Graves' disease who do not respond well to antithyroid medications, those with large goiters causing compressive symptoms, and those who are reluctant to undergo radioactive iodine (RAI) therapy. Relative indications for thyroidectomy include patients with moderate to severe Graves' ophthalmopathy, those who want rapid control of hyperthyroidism with the possibility of becoming euthyroid, and those who are non-compliant with antithyroid medications. However, surgery in pregnant women should only be used when rapid control is necessary and antithyroid medications cannot be used. The primary goal of thyroidectomy for Graves' disease is to achieve complete and permanent control of the disease with minimal morbidity. Patients should be made euthyroid before surgery with antithyroid drugs that should be continued up to the day of surgery. Lugol's iodide solution or saturated potassium iodide is generally administered starting 7 to 10 days before surgery to reduce the gland's vascularity and decrease the risk of precipitating thyroid storm. Postoperative monitoring of thyroid function and calcium levels is necessary to ensure that the patient is healing well and to detect any complications early on.

Random:

Propranolol is the preferred agent for β-blockade in hyperthyroidism and thyroid storm due to its additional effect blocking the peripheral conversion of inactive T4 to active form T3. Option: C. questions.correct_answer: C. Median age of survival is 6 months in advanced disease
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Median age of survival is 6 months in advanced disease Gallbladder carcinoma is a rare malignancy in the elderly and is associated with a poor prognosis and median survival is less than 6 months. Clinical features : Right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. Jaundice, palpable mass, and anorexia are late features. Gallbladder carcinoma is indistinguishable from cholecystitis or cholelithiasis . It is usually diagnosed when patients undergo cholecystectomy for gallstones CA 19-9 is elevated in the carcinoma gallbladder and is used for monitoring. Management Endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS) is considered more accurate than ultrasound (76%) and useful in differential diagnosis to detect histological neoplasia correctly MR cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) can help assess disease extent more accurately and properly identify unresectable candidates with hepatoduodenal ligament invasion, vasculature encasement , and/or lymph node involvement The most important prognostic factor is the depth of invasion (T-stage) Surgery is the only curative treatment for patients with Stage II or less and no contraindications

Highyeild:

Gallbladder cancer incidence varies by geographic region and racial-ethnic groups Highest incidence rates are observed among Chileans, Native Americans, and individuals in northern India Women have a higher incidence rate than men in all geographic areas Adenocarcinoma is the most common type of gallbladder cancer, accounting for 90% of cases Squamous carcinomas may arise from areas of mucosal squamous metaplasia Tumor is usually nodular and infiltrative , with thickening of the gallbladder wall, frequently extending throughout the entire gallbladder Patients with gallbladder cancer may be asymptomatic Symptoms are typically indistinguishable from those of benign gallbladder disease, such as biliary colic or cholecystitis , particularly in older patients Jaundice and anorexia are late features and often indicate a low resectability rate and fewer negative margins A palpable mass is a late sign

Extraedge:

Porcelain gallbladder is associated with a small increased risk of cancer Patients with PSC, especially those with concomitant inflammatory bowel disease, and those with an abnormal pancreatic-biliary junction are at greater risk of developing gallbladder cancer

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ileocolic Gastrointestinal tuberculosis (TB) accounts for 1% to 3 % of all TB cases worldwide. It can occur in the context of active pulmonary disease or as a primary infection without pulmonary involvement The terminal ileum and the cecum are the sites most commonly involved in abdominal TB. Symptoms : Abdominal pain, hematochezia, palpable mass in the abdomen along with fever, weight loss, anorexia, and night sweats. Modes of spread: By ingestion of infected food or milk (primary intestinal TB) or infected sputum (secondary intestinal TB) Contagious spread from infected adjacent foci Hematogenous spread from distant TB focus Through lymphatic channels Direct contact with an infected animal (Mycobacterium bovis) Medical Therapy : A standard four-drug regimen, consisting of isoniazid, rifampicin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol, is recommended for ATT in intra-abdominal/gastrointestinal tuberculosis. These four drugs are used thrice weekly for the initial two months, followed by isoniazid and rifampin for an additional four months

Causes and Risk Factors: tuberculosis is responsible for all cases of GI tuberculosis. bovis has largely been eliminated by public health measures. Intestinal tuberculosis is more common in poor socioeconomic status. Ingestion of contaminated food may cause primary tuberculosis. Tuberculous bacilli can be ingested through swallowed sputum. Primary intestinal tuberculosis can lead to secondary intestinal tuberculosis. The earliest intestinal lesions are found in the submucosa, while the overlying mucosa is normal. The most common site of involvement is the terminal ileum and ileocecal junction. Other affected regions, in decreasing frequency, include the colon, jejunum, rectum, anal canal, duodenum, stomach, and esophagus. Site of predilection is dictated by the abundance of lymphoid tissue, rate of absorption of intestinal contents, prolonged stasis, and digestive activity of intestinal contents. Clinical Features: Initial symptoms are vague and non-specific. As the disease progresses, individuals may develop fever, night sweats, malaise, weakness, anorexia, and weight loss. The most common symptom of GI tuberculosis is abdominal pain. Diarrhea is another common symptom. Abdominal distention suggests the presence of ascites or subacute intestinal obstruction. Diagnosis: The most common laboratory abnormality is a raised ESR. Ascitic fluid may show lymphocytosis, high protein content, SAAG <1.1, and raised adenosine deaminase. Radiological imaging, such as ultrasound and CT scans, can help diagnose GI tuberculosis. Barium studies can also help diagnose GI tuberculosis, with characteristic features such as the Fleishner or umbrella sign, string sign, Sterlein sign, and napkin ring stenosis. Treatment: The treatment of GI tuberculosis is ATT (anti-tuberculosis treatment) . Fever, malaise, and weight loss can subside in a few weeks. The majority of patients with symptoms of subacute intestinal obstruction and evidence of intestinal strictures show complete resolution of the radiological abnormality. Surgery may be necessary for intestinal obstruction secondary to stricture, free perforation, severe GI hemorrhage, intra-abdominal abscess, or internal or external fistula.

SSI - infected wound or deep organ space SIRS - body’s systemic response to severe infection Systemic infammatory response syndrome (SIRS) is a systemic manifestation of sepsis , although the syndrome may also be caused by multiple trauma, burns or pancreatitis without infection. Mechanism : Serious infection, such as secondary peritonitis, may lead to SIRS through the release of lipopolysaccharide endotoxin from the walls of dying Gram-negative bacilli (mainly Escherichia coli) or other bacteria or fungi. This and other toxins stimulate the release of cytokines from macrophages. Septic manifestations and multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS) in SIRS are mediated by the release of proinflammatory cytokines such as interleukin-1 (IL-1) and tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNFα). There are high circulating cytokine levels, and activated neutrophils stimulate fever, tachycardia, and tachypnoea. Gut failure, colonisation and translocation related to the development of systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) and multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS). IL, interleukin; TNF, tumour necrosis factor MODS - an effect that SIRS produces systemically The activated neutrophils adhere to vascular endothelium in key organs remote from the source of infection and damage it, leading to increased vascular permeability, which in turn leads to cellular damage within the organs, which become dysfunctional and give rise to the clinical picture of multiple organ dysfunction syndrome or MODS. MSOF - end stage of uncontrolled MODS Respiratory, cardiac, intestinal, renal, and liver failure ensue with circulatory failure and shock. Bridging Vessels The image showing a bleed over the arachnoid layer but under the dura suggests a subdural hemorrhage. Most commonly, it results from the shearing of cortical bridging veins Subdural hemorrhage (SDH) is a collection of blood between the dura and the arachnoid layers of the meninges Non-contrast CT is the investigation of choice. Middle meningeal artery rupture would result in an extradural hemorrhage Vertebral artery dissection leads to subarachnoid hemorrhage or sometimes intraparenchymal hemorrhage.

Acute Subdural Haematoma Type I : High-energy injury mechanisms can result in the rupture of cortical surface vessels with significant associated primary brain injury. This results in an expanding haematoma with rapid deterioration and development of signs of raised ICP reminiscent of extradural hematoma, without the lucid interval. These collections require prompt evacuation, typically by craniotomy or craniectomy. Type II : Older and often anticoagulated, a lower energy injury leads to venous bleeding around the brain. Depending on the total bleeding volume, the resulting hematoma may present early as acute subdural hematoma, after delay, and osmotic expansion as chronic subdural hematoma or may even remain clinically silent. Type III: Present much later with a further ‘acute-onchronic’ subdural hematoma. On diagnosis, the clotting function should be corrected wherever possible. Bleeds of significant size, with significantly associated midline shift or with deteriorating neurology, require urgent evacuation. Smaller bleeds in neurologically stable patients may be managed conservatively , at least initially: liquefaction of the clot over 7–10 days after the bleed may allow for a much less invasive evacuation through burr holes. Since the dura is not as adherent to the brain as to the skull, subdural blood is free to expand across the brain surface, giving a diffuse concave appearance. questions.text: A patient presents with multiple stab injuries to the chest. On examination, there was reduced chest movement on the right side and tracheal deviation to the left side. Neck veins distended Next best management is
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Needle Thoracocentesis Multiple stab injuries to the chest, reduced chest movement on the right side, tracheal deviation to the left side, and distension of neck veins suggest a diagnosis of tension pneumothorax on the right side. The next best step in the management is needle thoracocentesis. Tension pneumothorax is characterized by chest pain, tachypnea, tachycardia, hypotension, tracheal deviation away from the injury side, unilateral absence of breath sound, cyanosis, and neck vein distension. Treatment consists of immediate decompression, initially by rapidly inserting a large-bore cannula on the affected side. Tube thoracostomy is mandatory after needle or finger decompression of the chest and is the definitive management. The recent update (Acc. to ATLS 10th edition): In adults, the needle thoracotomy location was changed from the 2nd ICS midclavicular line to the 5th intercostal space (ICS) mid-axillary line. In the pediatric age group , the thoracotomy location remains the same at the 2nd ICS midclavicular line.

Highyeild:

Tension pneumothorax is a medical emergency that can result in respiratory failure or cardiovascular collapse. It can be diagnosed clinically without the need for radiographic confirmation. The symptoms of tension pneumothorax include deviation of the trachea , unilaterally absent or diminished breath sounds, and cardiopulmonary compromise. If these symptoms are present, thoracic decompression should be rapidly performed with a large-bore needle or tube thoracostomy, depending on the availability of equipment and supplies.

Extraedge:

In addition to tension pneumothorax, massive hemothorax also requires tube thoracostomy to evacuate blood and reexpansion the lung. Severe pulmonary contusion may require aggressive mechanical ventilation with elevated levels of positive end-expiratory pressure. However, to avoid loss of positive end-expiratory pressure, the ventilator should not be repeatedly disconnected for suction or manual ventilation as oxygenation will only improve with an uninterrupted circuit
